This slow growing fern can reach a height of up to 12 inches and a width of 24 inches. It is a popular landscaping choice as its wide, erect fronds make it attractive in garden borders. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5204,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pacific Island silvergrass","description":"Pacific Island silvergrass is a clumping, evergreen grass that grows in tropical climates. It is endemic to select Pacific islands and grows to about 4 to 5 feet tall. The species has large, silver-green leaves that form fluffy flowerheads with silky threads of golden-brown seeds. The flowering and seeding season is short, usually beginning in late summer and peaking in late fall. Pacific Island silvergrass has several uses, such as erosion control along roadsides, wildlife habitats, and as an ornamental grass in landscaping projects. It’s a great choice for low-water, low-maintenance gardens.","family":"Poaceae","flower_color":"Reddish tan","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Japan","Ryukyu Islands","Taiwan","Guam"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Division","Layering Propagation","Tissue Culture"],"pruning_month":["March","April","May","March","April","May"],"scientific_name":["Miscanthus floridulus"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5208,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_level":"Moderate","common_name":"eulalia","description":"Eulalia (Miscanthus sinensis 'Gracilimus') is an ornamental grass with delicate, arching, light-green leaves, and crimson-colored panicles of feathery flowers in summer. It is a clump-forming perennial grass, that features long, impressive, feathery plumes of tiny rose-colored flowers in late summer into fall. It grows 3-6 feet in height and 2-4 feet in width, and prefers full sun and rich, moist soil. It is an excellent choice for grassy hedges, screens or subtle dividers in gardens. Its fountain-shaped foliage is highly effective in garden beds and at the back of borders. Eulalia is widely admired for its tough nature, being one of the few grasses that can tolerate both dry and wet soils. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5202,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"sensitive brier","description":"Sensitive brier is a member of the Mimosa genus of plants native to North America. The plant grows in a variety of forms and sizes, from low shrubs to tall bushes. Its spiny foliage consists of bipinnate, alternate leaves that are 4-6 inches in length. The delicate white flowers and bright yellow compound pods of the sensitive brier make this plant a desirable addition to a garden. The stems, leaves, and pods are all covered in short green hairs, giving it a velvety texture. This plant is aptly named because the leaves fold up when touched, or “shiver”, similar to other Mimosa plants. As an added bonus, sensitive brier has a number of medicinal uses, and provides habitats for beneficial insects.","family":"Fabaceae","flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":["red","yellow","brown"],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Fall","leaf_color":["green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Central and South America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting","Layering Propagation","Division","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April","March","March","April","May","June","July","August"],"scientific_name":["Mimosa quadrivalvis"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5215,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_level":"Moderate","common_name":"eulalia","description":"Miscanthus sinensis 'Sarabande' is a clump-forming, deciduous ornamental grass. It has two angular, white-edged leaves, hence the common name “diphylla” for its species name. It produces upright clusters of little greenish-white or pinkish flowers with bracts resembling a Bishop’s miter. As the flowers fade, the seed heads resemble a small Brewer’s cap and turn a rich brown in the fall. It is a hardy plant, suitable for flower beds, borders, and rock gardens. It tolerates partial shade, acidic soil, and regular watering, making it an ideal choice for landscaping or center-pieces.","family":"Saxifragaceae","flower_color":"White","flowering_season":null,"fruit_color":[],"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":[],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":[],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Division","Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February","March","April"],"scientific_name":["Mitella diphylla"],"soil":[],"watering_period":null}}

The fragrant flowers attract pollinators such as hummingbirds, wild honeybees, and beneficial insects, making them perfect for a low-maintenance garden. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5264,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white mulberry","description":"The White Mulberry (Morus alba Doguwa) is a species of deciduous tree with a wide range of habitats. It can be found in the wild in moist valleys, along the coasts, in woodlands, and in grasslands. Growing up to 20 meters in height, its bark is rough and grey in color, and its leaves have serrated edges. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5289,"attracts":[],"care_level":null,"common_name":"grape hyacinth","description":"Grape hyacinth, or Muscari macrocarpum 'Golden Fragrance', is a beautiful, early spring-blooming bulb plant. They reach just 5-7 inches tall and boast mesmerizing, dense clusters of star-shaped, bright golden-yellow flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":5370,"attracts":[],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"trumpet daffodil","description":"The Trumpet Daffodil (Narcissus 'King Alfred') is a beautiful spring flower native to Europe, North Africa, and the Middle East.
